message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Bacterial species rarely work together
Paper Abstract: Competition is prevalent and could be harnessed as an alternative to antibiotics
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's an overview of antibiotics based on the search results:

## Definition and Purpose
An antibiotic is a type of antimicrobial substance active against bacteria. It is the most important type of antibacterial agent for fighting bacterial infections, and antibiotic medications are widely used in the treatment and prevention of such infections.

## How Antibiotics Work
The highest division between antibiotics is bactericidal and bacteriostatic. Bactericidals kill bacteria directly, whereas bacteriostatics prevent them from dividing.

## Classification
Antibiotics are classified generally as beta-lactams, macrolides, quinolones, tetracyclines or aminoglycosides.

## Historical Background
Antibiotics revolutionized medicine in the 20th century.(no content)Due to the discovery of penicillin by Alexander Fleming, and the efforts of Florey and Chain in 1938, large-scale, pharmaceutical production of antibiotics has been made possible.

## Antimicrobial Resistance
A significant concern today is antibiotic resistance. The effectiveness and easy access to antibiotics have also led to their overuse and some bacteria have evolved resistance to them.(no content)The World Health Organization has classified AMR as a widespread "serious threat [that] is no longer a prediction for the future, it is happening right now in every region of the world and has the potential to affect anyone, of any age, in any country". Each year, nearly 5 million deaths are associated with AMR globally.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Each year, nearly 5 million deaths are associated with AMR globally.

Links: [{"title":"Competition (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology)"},{"title":"Microbial cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_cooperation"},{"title":"Synthetic microbial consortia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_microbial_consortia"},{"title":"Microbiology of oxygen minimum zones - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiology_of_oxygen_minimum_zones"},{"title":"Branches of microbiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branches_of_microbiology"},{"title":"Synthetic biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_biology"},{"title":"Microbiology Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbiology_Society"},{"title":"Industrial microbiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_microbiology"},{"title":"Competitive exclusion principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_exclusion_principle"},{"title":"Carsonella ruddii - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carsonella_ruddii"}]

## Competition in Microbiology

Based on the search results, here's an overview of competition in the context of microbiology:

### General Concept of Competition

Competition is an interaction between organisms or species in which both require one or more resources that are in limited supply (such as food, water, or territory). In microbiology, this principle applies to how microorganisms interact with one another in shared environments.

### Competition in Microbial Communities

In a mixed community, different bacterial species have been found to adapt to different food sources,including the waste products of other species, in order to stave off unnecessary competition. This adaptation demonstrates how microbes organize themselves to reduce direct competition.

An interesting example involves siderophore production, where there must be equilibrium between the microbes that spend their energy to produce the chelating agents, and those that can utilize xenosiderophores; otherwise, the exploitative microbes would eventually out-compete the producers.

### Competition in Environmental Niches

In anoxic environments, the competition between ammonium and nitrite oxidization and anammox and denitrification for ammonium and nitrite play an important role in controlling nitrogen loss in oxygen minimum zones.

### Competitive Exclusion Principle

The competitive exclusion principle proposes that two species which compete for the same limited resource cannot coexist at constant population sizes. When one species has even the slightest advantage over another, the one with the advantage will dominate in the long term, leading either to the extinction of the weaker competitor or to an evolutionary or behavioral shift toward a different ecological niche.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Bacterial species"

Links: [{"title":"Bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacteria"},{"title":"Bacterial taxonomy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacterial_taxonomy"},{"title":"List of clinically important bacteria - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_clinically_important_bacteria"},{"title":"List of bacterial genera named after personal names - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_bacterial_genera_named_after_personal_names"},{"title":"List of bacteria genera - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_bacteria_genera"},{"title":"Bacterial cellular morphologies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacterial_cellular_morphologies"},{"title":"Bacteriology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacteriology"},{"title":"List of human microbiota - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_human_microbiota"},{"title":"List of bacterial orders - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_bacterial_orders"},{"title":"Bacterial phyla - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacterial_phyla"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about bacterial species:

## Overview

An estimated 43,000 species of bacteria have been named, though most of them have never been studied. However, research is heavily concentrated on a small subset: just 10 bacterial species account for half of all publications, whereas nearly 75% of all named bacteria have no academic research devoted to them.

## Taxonomy and Classification

The number of named species of bacteria and archaea (approximately 21,000) is surprisingly small considering their early evolution, genetic diversity and residence in all ecosystems. This discrepancy exists because bacteria divide asexually and for the most part do not show regionalisms ("Everything is everywhere"), therefore the concept of species, which works best for animals, becomes entirely a matter of judgment.(no content)Today the taxa which have been correctly described are reviewed in Bergey's manual of Systematic Bacteriology, which aims to aid in the identification of species and is considered the highest authority.

## Characteristics

Most bacterial species are either spherical, called cocci (singular coccus, from Greek kókkos, grain, seed), or rod-shaped, called bacilli (sing. bacillus, from Latin baculus, stick).(no content)Bacterial cells are typically 0.5–5.0 micrometres in length.

## Clinical and Health Significance

Several species of bacteria are pathogenic and cause infectious diseases, including cholera, syphilis, anthrax, leprosy, tuberculosis, tetanus and bubonic plague. Conversely, most of the bacteria in and on the body are harmless or rendered so by the protective effects of the immune system, and many are beneficial, particularly the ones in the gut.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity, entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results, relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
